title: Japanese submarine Ha-207
text:
Ha-207 was an <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> <a href="Ha-201-class%20submarine">"Ha-201"-class</a> <a href="submarine">submarine</a>. Completed and commissioned in August 1945 on the day before hostilities ended in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, she surrendered in September 1945 and was <a href="Scuttling">scuttled</a> in April 1946.
Design and description.
At the end of 1944, the Imperial Japanese Navy decided it needed large numbers of high-speed coastal submarines to defend the <a href="Japanese%20Archipelago">Japanese Home Islands</a> against an anticipated <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">Allied</a> invasion (named <a href="Operation%20Downfall">Operation Downfall</a> by the Allies). To meet this requirement, the "Ha-201"-class submarines were designed as small, fast submarines incorporating many of the same advanced ideas implemented in the German <a href="Type%20XXI%20submarine">Type XXI</a> and <a href="Type%20XXIII%20submarine">Type XXIII</a> submarines. They were capable of submerged speeds of almost .
The "Ha-201" class <a href="Displacement%20%28ship%29">displaced</a> surfaced and submerged. The submarines were long, had a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of and a <a href="draft%20%28hull%29">draft</a> of . For surface running, the submarines were powered by a single <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a> that drove one <a href="propeller%20shaft">propeller shaft</a>. When submerged the propeller was driven by a <a href="electric%20motor">electric motor</a>. They could reach on the surface and submerged. On the surface, the "Ha-201"-class submarines had a range of at ; submerged, they had a range of at . Their armament consisted of two <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s with four <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es and a single mount for a 7.7-millimeter <a href="machine%20gun">machine gun</a>.
Construction and commissioning.
"Ha-207" was <a href="Keel-laying">laid down</a> on 23 April 1945 by the <a href="Sasebo%20Naval%20Arsenal">Sasebo Naval Arsenal</a> at <a href="Sasebo">Sasebo</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>, as Submarine No. 4917. She was renamed Ha-207 on 1 May 1945 and was attached provisionally to the <a href="Sasebo%20Naval%20District">Sasebo Naval District</a> that day. She was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> simultaneously with her <a href="sister%20ship">sister ship</a> on 26 May 1945 and was completed and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 14 August 1945.
Service history.
Upon commissioning, "Ha-207" was attached formally to the Sasebo Naval District and assigned to Submarine Division 52. On 15 August 1945 — the day after "Ha-207" was commissioned — hostilities between Japan and the <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">Allies</a> ended. She surrendered to the Allies at Sasebo on 2 September 1945.
Disposal.
The Japanese struck "Ha-205" from the Navy list on 30 November 1945. She was <a href="scuttling">scuttled</a> along with the submarines , , , , , , and off <a href="Sasebo%20Bay">Sasebo Bay</a> on 5 April 1946.
